newsitem.title: USA: FCOJ futures close down as funds continue to sell.
newsitem.headline: FCOJ futures close down as funds continue to sell.

text.p: FCOJ futures settled lower for the second straight session as fund selling continued to erode recent gains, traders said.
Heavy selling emerged Monday when most-active September failed to hold above 78.00 cents a lb, where resistance was pegged.
Follow-through selling on the open pressured the benchmark contract through its downside target of 76.00 cents and to a low of 74.40 cents, where scale-down buying by the trade held the market.
Prices are expected to post further losses Wednesday, with support in September pegged at 74.05 cents, followed by 72.00 cents.
"The tone is still negative," said Celeste Georgakis, vice president with Dean Witter.
September settled 1.10 cents lower at 75.25 cents after trading from 76.35 to 74.40 cents. The rest finished 1.20 to 0.70 lower.
An estimated 3,000 lots changed hands on the day compared to Monday's official 2,359 lots.

Market analysts said a lack of news and a seasonal lull contributed to the recent dull tone. With the 1996/97 Florida harvest nearly complete, the market will wait until mid-August for the first private estimates for next year's crop.
Further, record U.S. and Brazilian crops, waning demand and high ending stocks will continue to weigh on the market, analysts said.
